Why: probability vs scientific value
- Detection probability: with current-generation terrestrial GW detectors, a GW signal from a core‑collapse supernova is only likely to be detectable within the Milky Way / very near Local Group. Galactic core‑collapse SNe occur ~2–3 per century on average, so the chance in a single year is O(1–5%) (uncertain and Poissonian). “Exotic” bursts have highly uncertain rates and amplitudes; most plausible models give low detection probability in any one year.
- Scientific payoff: a nearby core‑collapse SN or a convincing exotic GW burst with electromagnetic counterparts would be transformational — multi‑messenger observations would yield unique insights into explosion mechanisms, neutron star birth, nuclear physics and more. The upside is therefore very high.
- Expected utility argument: small probability × huge payoff can justify a small readiness cost, but not necessarily a large fixed annual spend dedicated only to those rare cases.

- Localization: non‑merger GW “burst” localizations are often very poor (large sky areas). Followup is expensive in telescope time unless you have wide‑field instruments or good priors (e.g., known nearby galaxies, neutrino coincidences).
- False alarms and vetting: rapid public alerts historically include many low‑significance candidates; you need a vetting/triage plan (automated ranking + human oversight) to avoid wasting resources.
- Latency: some EM counterparts evolve fast (shock breakout, early optical/UV), so automation and pre‑authorized ToO access are valuable.
- Multi‑messenger triggers: joint alerts (GW+neutrino, GW+gamma) drastically improve localization and credibility. Having protocols to ingest and act on combined alerts multiplies payoff.
- Reusability: investments in automation, scheduling, pipelines, and agreements are usable for lots of other science (transient surveys, GRBs, kilonovae), improving cost effectiveness.

What a cost‑effective program looks like (staged)
Stage 0 — minimal, low cost (recommended baseline)
- Implement automated alert ingestion, triage software, and a decision tree for triggers (who gets alerted, what telescopes are asked, criteria).
- Secure MOUs / pre‑approved ToO time on a mix of wide‑field survey telescopes (ZTF/LSST/BlackGEM equivalents, small robotic telescopes) and at least one medium aperture for deeper followup.
- Fund weekly/monthly drills and an on‑call rota (small FTE or shared duty among partners).
- Invest in software to cross‑match GW skymaps with galaxy catalogs and catalog of nearby star‑forming regions (to prioritize pointing).

Stage 1 — moderate expansion (if you want higher readiness)
- More guaranteed ToO nights on moderate telescopes, faster robotic slewing, prioritized computing/resources to run rapid image subtraction and candidate classification.
- Deeper, rapid spectroscopy capability agreements (partner arrangements rather than full ownership).
- Faster human vetting pipeline (dedicated part‑time staff).

Stage 2 — full expansion (only if justified by science program changes or new detector sensitivity)
- Dedicated wide‑field instruments, queue‑scheduled medium/large telescopes with guaranteed rapid access, expanded staffing, and sustained operational funding.

Operational rules to minimize wasted expense
- Prioritized triggers: e.g., act only on alerts above a ranking threshold, or on multi‑messenger coincident alerts, or when a nearby galaxy prior significantly narrows the search.
- Tiered response: initial wide shallow imaging (cheap) followed by deeper imaging/spectroscopy only for promising candidates.
- Review and “kill” criteria to stop followup when no credible EM candidates appear after reasonable effort.

Community coordination and leverage
- Work with GW collaborations and transient networks to refine alert content and vetting.
- Use archival and survey data (many searches for rare events can be done offline after the fact).
- Partner with other facilities to share the expense of readiness; community agreements reduce the need to buy your own instruments/time.

- Expected annual detection probability (P) for target event × scientific utility (U) vs program cost (C). If you estimate P is << 0.1, then only small C is justified unless U is enormous and you have high risk tolerance.

2. Defer large capital/telescope time commitments until (a) detector sensitivity/localization materially improves, (b) alert rates/qualities change, or (c) you obtain additional community commitments. Reassess after the next observing run or after any significant GW candidate announcements.

4. Run an exercise (tabletop + real practice with simulated alerts) to quantify operational costs and telescope time needed for a credible search.

Bottom line
Do not fund an expensive, single‑purpose program whose only payoff is an unlikely nearby non‑merger GW detection. text: Draft criteria for prioritizing electromagnetic follow-up observations for potential LIGO alerts from non-merger sources. Should we treat these as high priority given the scientific payoff, or lower priority given detection uncertainty?
proposition: LIGO or another gravitational wave detector will observe gravitational waves from a new type of source (not binary mergers) before 2030.
response_text:
Short answer
- Treat non‑merger LIGO alerts on a case‑by‑case basis. They can have very high scientific payoff (potentially new source classes), but they often come with higher detection uncertainty and poorer localization than compact‑binary alerts. Prioritize them when objective evidence raises the probability of a real, observable counterpart; otherwise give them lower priority or cheap/archival follow‑up.  
- Implement a simple decision rule (score or tier system) that combines detection significance, expected EM counterpart brightness/timescale, localization and galaxy information, multi‑messenger coincidences, observability and cost. Use that score to allocate observing resources proportionally.

Detailed, practical criteria and a decision framework
Use the following factors to decide whether and how urgently to follow up a non‑merger GW alert. For each incoming alert evaluate these items quickly and then use a numeric or tiered decision rule.

1) Detection confidence / astrophysical probability
- FAR (false alarm rate): lower FAR → higher priority. If FAR is reported, use it; if not, use LVC "significance" or any provided P_astro.  
- P_astro (if provided) is the best single number: higher P_astro → higher priority.

2) Source plausibility and predicted EM signature
- Source class (if given): e.g., unmodeled burst, core‑collapse supernova candidate, magnetar flare, ringdown, continuous wave trigger. Some classes have expected bright early EM emission (core collapse, magnetar flares), others may not.  
- Theoretical EM brightness and timescale: is prompt high‑energy/optical emission expected? Hours, days, weeks? Faster timescales demand faster follow‑up.

3) Multi‑messenger coincidences
- Coincident neutrino or high‑energy gamma detections (IceCube, Fermi, Swift, etc.) greatly increase priority even if FAR is modest.  
- Known transient seen by wide‑field survey at compatible time/location increases priority.

4) Localization and distance information
- Sky localization area: small area → easier and higher priority. Very large areas (>1000 deg2) usually lower priority unless other factors compensate.  
- Distance estimate and overlap with galaxy catalogs: well‑localized events that coincide with nearby (tens to a few hundred Mpc) galaxies are much higher priority.

5) Observability and timing constraints
- Is the localization region currently observable from your facility? Is the source above horizon, at acceptable airmass, and outside twilight?  
- Does the predicted EM counterpart fade quickly (requiring immediate action) or evolve slowly (allowing scheduled observations)?

6) Resource cost and capability
- Field of view, depth, number of pointings required, and time to tile the area. Cheap wide‑field facilities can do low‑cost initial coverage; deep narrow‑field facilities should be reserved for higher priority cases or candidate followups.  
- Human and scheduling costs for interrupting other programs.

7) Scientific payoff and uniqueness
- Potential to discover a new class or provide unique physics (e.g., prompt EM from a GW burst) increases weight. Also consider whether other teams/instruments are likely to cover the event.

Suggested scoring / prioritization recipe (simple, actionable)
- Normalize factors to 0–1 (0 = worst/least plausible, 1 = best). Example factors: F = detection confidence (P_astro or 1–scaled FAR), S = source EM plausibility/expected brightness, L = localization usefulness (small area/galaxy association), M = multi‑messenger flag (0 or 1), O = observability (0–1), C = cost penalty (1 = cheap to follow, 0 = prohibitively expensive).  
- PriorityScore = wF*F + wS*S + wL*L + wM*M + wO*O + wC*C. Choose weights to reflect your program priorities; an example set: wF=0.25, wS=0.25, wL=0.2, wM=0.15, wO=0.1, wC=0.05.  
- Map PriorityScore to tiers:
  - Tier 1 (Immediate / high priority): score > 0.7 — execute rapid ToO, wide‑field tiling plus deep followup of candidate galaxies/candidates.
  - Tier 2 (Medium): 0.4–0.7 — schedule followup within hours–days; low‑cost wide‑field monitoring; prioritize candidates found by others.
  - Tier 3 (Low): <0.4 — archival search, shallow monitoring if cheap, or no action.

Practical threshold examples (operational templates you can adapt)
- Immediate high priority if any of the following are true:
  - P_astro > 0.5 (if available), OR
  - FAR better than an internal threshold (e.g., <1 per month) AND (localization area < 200 deg2 OR strong galaxy association within ~200 Mpc), OR
  - Coincident neutrino / gamma‑ray detection OR contemporaneous transient seen in EM surveys.  
- Medium priority if: 0.1 < P_astro < 0.5 OR FAR between ~1/month and 1/year with reasonable localization or plausible EM counterpart timescale.  
- Low priority / archival only if: P_astro < 0.1 and FAR poor (>1/year), localization huge (>1000 deg2), no expected prompt EM, and no multi‑messenger corroboration.

Observing strategy guidance by priority
- Tier 1 (High): Rapid wide‑field coverage within minutes–hours for fast transients; galaxy‑targeted deep imaging for smaller localization region; coordinate spectroscopic follow‑up of promising candidates; trigger radio/X‑ray if predicted. Produce image subtraction and rapid candidate vetting.  
- Tier 2 (Medium): Monitor large region with survey cadence (hours–days); obtain deeper imaging of top galaxy candidates; schedule spectroscopy only for credible candidates.  
- Tier 3 (Low): Perform archival/stacked searches and targeted observations of the most promising single galaxies only; no large ToO commitment.

Additional operational recommendations
- Always check for external coincidences (neutrinos, gamma, optical transients) — these can change priority dramatically.  
- Use galaxy catalogs (GLADE, CLU, etc.) to prioritize pointings for nearby events.  
- Keep a low‑cost "default" response: e.g., a single shallow wide‑field exposure or automated stacking that costs little but can catch bright fast counterparts.  
- Report non‑detections and limits quickly and in a standardized format; non‑detections constrain models and are valuable.  
- Maintain an internal FAR/P_astro threshold policy that balances scientific ambition and available resources; revisit after a few alerts to tune thresholds.

Final recommendation (balance risk vs payoff)
- Because non‑merger GW alerts carry both high discovery potential and substantial uncertainty, they should not be universally treated as highest priority, nor as negligible. Adopt a conditional prioritization policy: reserve top resources for cases with substantive evidence (low FAR / high P_astro, small localization or galaxy match, or multi‑messenger corroboration) and use inexpensive wide‑field or archival strategies for low‑confidence alerts. This conserves scarce high‑impact follow‑up time while preserving sensitivity to rare, high‑value discoveries.

- produce a one‑page flowchart/decision tree you can print for observers, or  
- convert the scoring recipe into a small spreadsheet or script with example weights and normalization so your team can apply it automatically on incoming alerts.

text: Should I tell my audience that LIGO detecting gravitational waves from something other than colliding black holes is likely in the next few years, or am I overhyping it?
proposition: LIGO or another gravitational wave detector will observe gravitational waves from a new type of source (not binary mergers) before 2030.
response_text:
Short answer: you can say it’s plausible, but be cautious about tone and specifics. Some non–black-hole sources have already been seen (so it’s not wildly speculative), while others remain possible but uncertain on a "next few years" timescale.

Key points to use when you communicate this

- What LIGO already did: LIGO/Virgo have detected binary neutron-star (BNS) and neutron-star–black-hole (NSBH) mergers (so “something other than colliding black holes” is not just theoretical). Cite LVC catalogs (GWTC).
- Most likely near-term new kinds of detections:
  - More BNS and NSBH events (very likely as sensitivity and run time increase).
  - Continuous waves from spinning neutron stars — plausible within a few years but far from guaranteed; depends on unknown ellipticities and improved sensitivity/search methods.
  - A stochastic background (from many unresolved binaries) — possible within the next several years to decade depending on the true astrophysical amplitude and network sensitivity.
- Less likely in the next few years:
  - A gravitational-wave signal from a core-collapse supernova unless one occurs in our Galaxy or a very nearby galaxy (Galactic supernovae are rare).
  - Exotic signals (cosmic strings, primordial signals) are speculative and low probability on short timescales.
- Instrumental context: detection prospects improve with each observing run and with network upgrades (O4 completed, O5 and further upgrades expected to increase sensitivity). That’s why probabilities change over time.

How to phrase it (pick your audience)

- Short/press-friendly: “It’s plausible we’ll see gravitational waves from sources other than black-hole binaries in the coming years — we already have neutron-star mergers, and searches for continuous waves and a stochastic background could pay off as detectors get more sensitive. But some targets (like supernovae) require a lucky nearby event.”
- More cautious/technical: “BNS and NSBH detections are established; additional classes such as continuous waves or a stochastic background are realistic possibilities as LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA sensitivity improves, but the timing is uncertain and depends on source properties and rates.”
- Avoid categorical language like “will” or “definitely.” Use “possible,” “plausible,” or “likely” only when the underlying detection probability is indeed high (e.g., more BNS/NSBH).

If you want to be precise for readers, add a sentence explaining why uncertainty exists: detector sensitivity, event rates, and unknown source strengths all matter.

Sources to cite or point readers to
- LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA public pages and observing run summaries
- The latest LVC detection catalog (GWTC)
- LIGO science summaries about continuous waves, stochastic background, and supernova prospects

text: I'm writing an undergraduate astrophysics textbook that will be published in 2025. Should I include a section on anticipated gravitational wave detections from supernovae and other exotic sources, presenting them as likely imminent discoveries? Or is that setting students up for disappointment?
proposition: LIGO or another gravitational wave detector will observe gravitational waves from a new type of source (not binary mergers) before 2030.
response_text:
Short answer: include the material — but not as a claim that detections are “imminent.” Present it as an active, high‑priority area with plausible near‑term opportunities (especially if a core‑collapse supernova occurs in the Galaxy) and a realistic discussion of why many proposed sources remain speculative. Give students the physics and the detection‑prospects tools so they can judge likelihoods themselves, and plan to keep the text’s online supplement updatable.

Why this tone
- GW astronomy has clear, robust successes (binary black hole and binary neutron star mergers). That motivates covering future prospects.
- Core‑collapse supernovae and many “exotic” sources (cosmic strings, certain instabilities in newborn neutron stars, some primordial scenarios) are plausible GW emitters but their amplitudes, rates, and waveforms are uncertain. Detectability depends strongly on source energy in GWs, waveform morphology, frequency, and distance — many of which are poorly constrained.
- If you present detection as a near‑certainty you risk students forming a misleading impression; science textbooks are a place to teach how to evaluate uncertainty and risk.

How to present it in the book (practical guidance)
- Include a dedicated section or boxed feature titled something like “Prospects for future gravitational‑wave detections: supernovae and exotic sources.”
- Framing paragraph (suggested wording you can adapt):
  “Gravitational‑wave detectors have already opened a new window on compact‑object mergers. Other predicted GW sources — notably asymmetric core‑collapse supernovae and a variety of exotic mechanisms — remain unconfirmed. A Galactic core collapse would almost certainly produce a detectable GW signal with current detectors; by contrast, detections from typical extragalactic supernovae or many exotic scenarios generally require substantially greater sensitivity and/or favorable source physics. These searches therefore remain an active and rapidly evolving area of research rather than a settled expectation.”
- Emphasize three concrete takeaways:
  1. A core‑collapse supernova in the Milky Way is the most promising “imminent” discovery scenario for bursts. (But Milky Way supernovae are rare — a few per century.)
  2. Typical extragalactic core collapse (at Mpc distances) is unlikely to be detectable with current second‑generation detectors unless the GW emission is much stronger than many models predict.
  3. Exotic sources are speculative; they are worth studying because a discovery would be transformative, but one should not promise outcomes.
- Give students the physics and tools to evaluate claims:
  - Explain qualitative emission mechanisms in core collapse (asymmetric collapse, convective motions, rotational instabilities, standing accretion shock instability, proto‑NS oscillations).
  - Describe detection concepts: matched filtering vs. burst searches, signal‑to‑noise ratio scaling with distance and detector noise, role of frequency band and waveform duration.
  - Show sensitivity curves for present detectors (Advanced LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA) and planned upgrades/next‑generation detectors (A+, Voyager, Einstein Telescope, Cosmic Explorer), and explicitly explain how sensitivity improvements change horizon distances and rates.
  - Provide simple order‑of‑magnitude estimates and exercises (see examples below).
- Use uncertainty‑aware language throughout (words like “plausible,” “could be,” “if,” “would be detectable if,” “requires”) rather than categorical predictions.
- Provide references and point students to continuously updated resources (LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA public pages, review articles, and arXiv).

Sample classroom/exercise ideas
- Compute detectability: give students a model GW energy E_GW emitted at characteristic frequency f and distance R, and estimate characteristic strain and SNR against a given detector noise curve. Let them explore how detectability changes if E_GW varies by orders of magnitude.
- Compare detection horizons: assume a canonical E_GW for a core collapse and compute the maximum distance for which current detectors would have SNR≥8. Repeat for next‑generation sensitivities.
- Ask students to evaluate how waveform morphology (narrowband vs broadband burst) affects optimal search strategy and SNR.
- Literature exercise: review recent LVC supernova search papers and summarize constraints placed on E_GW.

Suggested short caveats for the book’s copy-editing stage
- Add an “as of [month year]” statement for the section and commit to an online erratum/supplement that can be updated between manuscript acceptance and publication. (Because GW results evolve quickly, this lets you keep predictions current without locking the printed text to a date.)
- Before finalizing proofs, check the latest LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA publication page and major review articles for any new detections or strong upper limits.

References and reviews (to include or check for updates)
- LIGO Scientific Collaboration & Virgo Collaboration discovery and overview papers (many useful review-style LVC articles exist).
- Review articles on GW emission from core collapse (e.g., reviews by Ott, Janka, Müller — check the most recent versions).
- Papers/reviews on exotic sources and stochastic backgrounds.
(Consult current literature for 2024–2025 updates before final text.)

Bottom line
Include the topic, but do so as an informed, cautious forecast and a good pedagogical opportunity to teach how observational prospects are assessed. That both excites students about frontier research and avoids promising outcomes that may not occur on a short timescale. Make the text easy to update (online supplement, “as of” date), and give students quantitative tools to form their own judgments.

- Produce one or two homework problems (with solutions) that estimate detectability for a core‑collapse supernova and for an exotic source.
